title: 108_hr1800
content: The United States aims to end animal suffering caused by steel-jawed leghold traps by banning their import, export, and interstate shipment, along with fur from animals trapped in such devices. Prohibited acts and penalties are outlined in the policy. It is illegal to import, export, or transport steel-jawed leghold traps or fur from animals trapped in them across state lines. Prohibited acts and penalties are specified in the policy. Violation of rules made by the Secretary under the Act carries penalties. For the first offense, imprisonment for up to 5 days or a fine under title 18, United States Code, or both may be imposed. Subsequent violations may result in imprisonment for up to two years or a fine under title 18, United States Code, or both. The Secretary will reward individuals who provide information leading to a conviction under the Act with half of the fine paid. Government officials are not eligible for rewards. Enforcement of the Act includes penalties such as imprisonment or fines. The Secretary enforces the Act and rules with the help of other agencies. Import violations are treated as customs law violations. States shall apply Export Administration Act of 1979 to enforce provisions related to export violations. Enforcement authorities can detain, search, and seize packages with reasonable cause. Enforcement authorities can detain, search, and seize packages with reasonable cause, and make arrests without a warrant for violations of the Act committed in their presence or with probable cause. Enforcement authorities can detain, search, and seize packages with reasonable cause, and make arrests without a warrant for violations of the Act committed in their presence or with probable cause. They can also execute and serve warrants issued by a judge or magistrate for enforcement of the Act, except for certain violations. Forfeiture rules apply, except for specific exports and imports regulated by other laws. Customs laws of the United States state that any fur article or steel-jawed leghold trap in violation of the Act shall be subject to forfeiture. This includes seizure, forfeiture, and disposition of such property. The customs laws of the United States allow for the seizure, forfeiture, and disposition of property or proceeds from the sale, remission or mitigation of forfeitures, and compromise of claims under the Act. Enforcement duties can be carried out by customs officers or other individuals as applicable. States may conduct seizures and forfeitures of property under this subsection by authorized officers or agencies designated by the Secretary. The Attorney General can seek injunctions against those violating the Act, and cooperation is required from various departments and agencies. The Treasury, along with other enforcement agencies, must cooperate with the Secretary to ensure effective enforcement of this Act and its rules. SEC. 5. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, the term "article of fur" refers to furskins or articles made in whole or part of furskin. The term "conventional steel-jawed leghold trap" is defined as a spring-powered device with two opposing steel jaws. The term "import" means to bring into the United States, regardless of whether it enters the customs territory. The term "customs laws of the United States" refers to laws enforced by the United States Customs Service. The term "interstate commerce" is defined in section 10 of title 18, US Code, and the term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of the Interior. The Secretary has the authority to create rules for implementing the Act, which will become effective one year after its enactment.
